abstracts.cdata!:
The ratings for the project were as
            follows: the outcome was satisfactory, the sustainability
            was likely, the institutional development impact was high,
            and the Bank and borrower performance were both
            satisfactory. The lessons learned indicate that experience
            with biodiversity projects also indicates the importance of
            facilitating biodiversity conservation activities by
            communities or groups of people who have a vital interest in
            conservation, either because their livelihoods depend
            directly on biological resources, or because their quality
            of life depends significantly on use and existence values of
            biodiversity. Brazukuab Biodiversity Fund (FUNBIO's)
            design reflected learning from the earliest generation of
            GEF supported trust funds for biodiversity conservation. A
            lesson identified in GEF's global portfolio of trust
            funds was that trust funds can promote decreases in
            government funding of protected areas by substituting trust
            fund financing for regular appropriations. At the time the
            project was designed, there was an expectation that the
            companion project would support definition of clear
            priorities and targets for biodiversity conservation
            outcomes, and that FUNBIO would incorporate the objectives,
            indicators, and measurement systems related to those
            outcomes into the monitoring and evaluation system for its
            own projects.

repnme.cdata!:
Brazil - National Biodiversity and
            Brazilian Biodiversity Fund Projects

abstracts.cdata!:
The main objective of the National
            Biodiversity Project is to assist the government to initiate
            a program for the conservation and sustainable use of
            biodiversty by identifying priority actions; simulating the
            development of sub-projects through the facilitation of
            partnerships between the public and private sectors; and
            disseminating biodiversity information. The project will
            include the following components: 1) biodiversity
            assessments and dissemination, which will include a
            biodiversity information network; 2) model biodiversity
            sub-projects; and 3) project administration. The main
            objective of the Brazilian Biodiversity Fund (FUNBIO)
            Project is to provide long-term and sustainable use of
            biological diversity in Brazil. The project will have two
            major components: 1) strengthening and operational support
            of FUNBIO, which will include operational costs, development
            of a cost-recovery and fund-raising program, and special
            studies to strengthen FUNBIO; and 2) grants program that
            will finance FUNBIO sub-projects. The sub-projects will be
            selected on a competitive basis according to established
            criteria. The nature of the sub-projects will include the
            following four broad areas: (a) biodiversity conservation;
            (b) sustainable use of biodiversity; (c) policy analysis;
            and (d) applied research and technology development.
